sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a reaction involving acids and bases
message_1: What is the standard enthalpy change for the neutralization of hydrochloric acid (HCl) with sodium hydroxide (NaOH) to form sodium chloride (NaCl) and water (H2O), given that the reaction takes place at standard conditions?
message_2:
The standard enthalpy change for the neutralization of hydrochloric acid (HCl) with sodium hydroxide (NaOH) to form sodium chloride (NaCl) and water (H2O) can be determined using the following balanced chemical equation:

HCl(aq) + NaOH(aq) → NaCl(aq) + H2O(l)

The standard enthalpy change for this reaction, also known as the enthalpy of neutralization, is approximately -57.32 kJ/mol. This value represents the amount of heat released when one mole of HCl reacts with one mole of NaOH under standard conditions (25°C and 1 atm pressure).
